text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.2.3, Use of Force Procedures.

Subsection 9.2.3.7.1(1)d) has been updated to reflect that a copy of Form 9776, Use of Force Incident Report, and narrative must be sent to Director, National CI Training Academy (NCITA), Attention: Use of Force Senior Analyst.

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.2.3 dated January 30, 2014. This IRM also incorporates implemented by the Chief, Criminal Investigation, guidance memorandum dated September 10, 2014, “Active Threat Preparedness and Response”].

establishes guidelines consistent with a uniform Treasury standard for law enforcement officers to use in making decisions regarding emergency driving. (

) The goal of this directive is to ensure the safety of law enforcement officers, other persons involved, and the general public by balancing the seriousness the emergency with safety considerations. (
) Directive No.

applies when a suspect is being followed to make an appre- hension, surveillance is being conducted, or exigent circumstances exist. following a suspect vehicle to make an apprehension conducting surveillance responding to other exigent circumstances

) When balancing the need for emergency driving with safety considerations, special agents should consider all relevant factors, including but not limited the following: a. the nature of the emergency b. the imminent danger to public safety if a suspect is not apprehended c. the seriousness of the offense d. the probability of apprehending a suspect at a later time e. the location, weather, speed, traffic, and road conditions f. the time of day g. the presence of pedestrians h. the special agent’s driving ability i. the condition of all the vehicles involved j. the availability of emergency equipment k. the availability of assistance from uniformed police officers in marked police vehicles l. the possibility of alternative courses of action (

) In some circumstances, emergency driving tactics may constitute the use deadly force. Those emergency driving tactics that are likely to cause serious physical injury may constitute the use of deadly force. Special may use deadly force only when necessary; that is, when the special agent has a reasonable belief that the subject of such force poses an imminent danger of death or serious physical injury to the special agent or to person. (

) Deadly force may be used to prevent the escape of a fleeing subject if probable cause to believe: a. The subject has committed a felony involving the infliction or infliction of serious physical injury or death; or b. The escape of the subject would pose an imminent danger of death or serious physical injury to the officer or to another person. (
